head.title: Scrambling for Parking as JetBlue Adds Flights

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Manufacturing, Operations and Logistics

hedline.hl1: Scrambling for Parking as JetBlue Adds Flights

abstract.p: Officials in Westchester County, NY, anticipating heavy air travel during Easter and Passover holidays and citing shortage of parking, recommends that travelers use alternative transportation to Westchester County Airport (S)

block.p: Just in time for spring break, JetBlue Airways began service to Florida from Westchester County Airport last week, and by the end of the week the airline will offer four departures and arrivals a day serving Fort Lauderdale, West Palm Beach and Orlando.

The only hitch for those heading south is that they should plan on getting a ride to the airport, because parking is limited. Last week, before JetBlue started its Florida runs, the parking lots were nearly full.

Just in time for spring break, JetBlue Airways began service to Florida from Westchester County Airport last week, and by the end of the week the airline will offer four departures and arrivals a day serving Fort Lauderdale, West Palm Beach and Orlando.

The only hitch for those heading south is that they should plan on getting a ride to the airport, because parking is limited. Last week, before JetBlue started its Florida runs, the parking lots were nearly full.

Now, anticipating thousands of additional travelers during the Easter and Passover holidays, the county is recommending that travelers use alternative transportation, like the Bee-Line bus service from the White Plains Trans Center or taxis and limousines. (For a list of companies offering discounts, go to the county's Web site, westchestergov.com.)

For years, Westchester County Airport has served mostly business travelers, and the garage (with 1,100 spaces, and another 250 available in a separate overflow area) was sufficient. Since last spring, however, when AirTran Airways began service to Florida, the parking lots started to fill up with travelers from Westchester and Fairfield Counties. AirTran increased the number of Florida flights from 4 in April 2006 to 11 in February, and last week there were only 30 spaces to spare.
''Last January, we were getting 43,000 passengers inbound and outbound,'' said Peter Scherrer, the airport's manager. ''This January, we had 80,000.''
Now, with JetBlue in service, the airport is getting close to its maximum allowable rate of 240 passengers per half-hour.
''We're getting to the point where we are going to have the perfect mix, where we hit the capacity limit for serving the needs of the community,'' Mr. Scherer said.

Finding solutions to the parking situation, however, is not going to be easy because the airport, surrounded by wetlands, has a no-expansion policy. The county is considering options including providing park-and-ride service from other county parking lots and limited construction of long-term parking on airport property.

''We want people who travel out of Westchester County Airport to have a pleasurable experience, and we don't want them to ride around the airport looking for a parking spot that doesn't exist,'' said Susan Tolchin, the chief adviser to the county executive, Andrew J. Spano. ''Therefore, we are encouraging them to leave their cars at home.''
